sub_subject.name: Old Testament Studies (Canonical Survey)
sub_subject.description: 13-year academic progression (K-12) for Old Testament Studies (Canonical Survey) (Bible & Theology)

objectives.objective_text: Identify Genesis as the book of 'Beginnings'.
Identify Numbers as the book where they counted the people.
Name the 12 spies who went into the land.
Identify this book as a history of God's kings.
Name David and Solomon as the main heroes.
Identify Solomon as the wise king who built the Temple.
Name Elijah as the prophet who went up to heaven.
Identify Samuel as the boy who heard God call him.
Name David and Goliath.
Identify Esther as a Jewish queen.
Name Mordecai as her wise cousin.
Identify Ezra as a teacher of God's Word.
Name the Temple as what they built again.
Identify Joshua as the leader who fought the Battle of Jericho.
Name Rahab as the woman who helped the spies.
Identify Samson and Gideon.
Name the Judges as leaders before there were kings.
Identify Nehemiah as the cupbearer to the king.
Name the Wall of Jerusalem as what they built.
Identify Ruth as a loyal daughter-in-law.
Name Boaz as the kind man.
Identify Daniel as the man who prayed in the lions' den.
Name Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego.
Identify Ezekiel as the prophet with strange visions.
Name the Valley of Dry Bones.
Identify Isaiah as a prophet who saw God on a throne.
Name 'Immanuel' (God with us).
Identify Jeremiah as the 'Weeping Prophet'.
Name the potter and the clay story.
Identify Amos as a shepherd.
Name justice as being fair to everyone.
Identify Habakkuk as a man who asked God questions.
Name the watchtower where he waited.
Identify Haggai as a prophet after the exile.
Name the Temple as what needed building.
Identify Hosea as the man who married Gomer.
Name God's love as a never-stopping love.
Identify the locusts as bugs that ate everything.
Name the 'Day of the Lord'.
Identify Jonah as the man swallowed by a big fish.
Name Nineveh as the city he didn't want to go to.
Identify Malachi as the last book of the Old Testament.
Name God as a Father.
Identify Micah as a prophet.
Name Bethlehem as the place a Ruler would come from.
Identify Nahum as a prophet against a bad city.
Name Nineveh again (after Jonah).
Identify Obadiah as a short book.
Name Edom as the enemy.
Identify Zechariah as a prophet with strange dreams.
Name the King coming on a donkey.
Identify Zephaniah as a prophet.
Name the 'Day of the Lord'.
Identify Deuteronomy as Moses' last speech.
Name the command to love God with all our heart.
Identify Exodus as the book about leaving Egypt.
Name Moses as the leader God chose.
Name the first man and woman made by God.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Identify rules (Law) and good news (Gospel).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Name Jesus as the one who kept the rules for us.
Identify Leviticus as a book about holiness.
Name the priests as helpers in God's house.
Identify that there is a time for everything.
Name the 'Preacher' who looked for happiness.
Identify Job as a man who loved God but suffered.
Name God as the one who is in charge of everything.
Identify Proverbs as a book of wise sayings.
Name Solomon as the wisest king.
Identify Psalms as songs to God.
Name David as a writer of songs.
Identify this book as a song about love.
Name marriage as a special gift from God.
Recall that the people complained a lot in the desert.
Observe the cloud that led them by day.
Recall that they loved the Temple.
Observe that lists of names show God remembers everyone.
Recall that the kingdom broke into two pieces.
Observe that bad kings made the people worship idols.
Recall that Saul was the first king, but David was the best king.
Observe that David loved God with all his heart.
Recall that she was brave to talk to the king.
Observe that God saved His people from bad Haman.
Recall that the people came back home from Babylon.
Observe that they were happy to read the Bible again.
Recall that the walls fell down when they shouted.
Observe that God keeps His promises to give them the land.
Recall that the people forgot God many times.
Observe that God saved them when they prayed.
Recall that they worked with a tool in one hand and a sword in the other.
Observe that Nehemiah prayed before he acted.
Recall that Ruth picked up grain in the fields.
Observe that King David came from Ruth's family.
Recall that God rules over all kings.
Observe the writing on the wall.
Recall that God can make dead things alive.
Observe the vision of the wheels with eyes.
Recall that he said Jesus would die for our sins.
Observe the vision of the wolf lying down with the lamb.
Recall that he told people to stop sinning.
Observe that God promised a New Covenant.
Recall that God wants us to help the poor.
Observe that God sees how we treat others.
Recall 'The righteous shall live by faith'.
Observe that we can rejoice even when things are hard.
Recall that the people were building their own houses instead.
Observe that God wants to be first.
Recall that God forgives us when we run away.
Observe that God wants us to love Him back.
Recall that God promised to pour out His Spirit.
Observe that we should pray when bad things happen.
Recall that God loves people everywhere.
Observe that you can't run away from God.
Recall that the people were robbing God.
Observe that God promised to send Elijah before the end.
Recall that God wants us to be kind and humble.
Observe that God forgives sin.
Recall that God is slow to anger but strong.
Observe that God protects those who trust Him.
Recall that we shouldn't laugh when others get hurt.
Observe that God defends His people.
Recall that it is 'Not by might, nor by power, but by My Spirit'.
Observe that God cares about Jerusalem.
Recall that God sings over His people.
Observe that God will clean up the world.
Recall that obedience brings blessings.
Observe that God wants us to remember His laws.
Recall the crossing of the Red Sea.
Observe the Ten Commandments as God's rules.
Recall the story of Noah's Ark.
Observe that God made everything good.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Recall that we cannot keep all the rules perfectly.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Observe that God forgives us when we fail.
Recall that God wants His people to be clean.
Observe that sin is serious.
Recall that only God can make us truly happy.
Observe that toys break and don't last forever.
Recall that Job did not stop loving God even when sad.
Observe that God made the Behemoth and Leviathan.
Recall that listening to parents is wise.
Observe the difference between a wise child and a foolish one.
Recall 'The Lord is my Shepherd'.
Observe that we can sing when happy or sad.
Recall that God loves His people very much.
Observe that husband and wife are best friends.
Produce a reflection on finding joy in the simple gifts of God.
Categorize Genesis as the foundation for the rest of the Bible.
Summarize the rebellion at Kadesh Barnea.
Explain why they wandered for 40 years (one year for each day spied).
Explain the transition from the old generation to the new generation.
Perform research on the geography of the wilderness journey.
Summarize the theme: The Fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom.
Summarize the focus on the Temple and worship.
Explain that Chronicles retells the story of Samuel/Kings.
Explain the theme of 'seeking the Lord'.
Perform research on the post-exilic context.
Summarize the story of Elijah on Mount Carmel.
Explain why the kingdom divided (Rehoboam).
Categorize kings as 'Good' (like Hezekiah) or 'Bad' (like Ahab).
Explain the sin of Jeroboam (golden calves).
Defend the justice of the Exile based on covenant curses.
Produce a study on the contest between Yahweh and Baal.
Summarize the transition from Judges to Kings.
Explain why God chose David (looks at the heart).
Explain the political unification of the tribes under David.
Perform research on the historiography of the 'Court History of David'.
Summarize how Esther became queen.
Explain the plot to destroy the Jews.
Explain the vulnerability of Jews in the diaspora.
Defend the doctrine of Providence using Esther as a case study.
Produce an essay on anti-semitism in the ancient world.
Summarize the decree of Cyrus allowing the return.
Explain the opposition to building the Temple.
Explain the role of the scribe.
Defend the continuity of the covenant despite the lack of a king.
Summarize the crossing of the Jordan and the fall of Jericho.
Explain the sin of Achan.
Explain the concept of Herem (Holy War/Devoted to Destruction).
Perform research on the Amarna Letters and the Habiru.
Summarize the cycle of Judges: Sin, Oppression, Repentance, Deliverance.
Explain how Gideon defeated the Midianites.
Categorize the enemies (Philistines, Moabites, etc.).
Explain the role of the Holy Spirit coming upon the Judges.
Defend the sovereignty of God in using flawed human instruments.
Produce an essay on the spiral of apostasy.
Summarize how Nehemiah organized the people to build.
Explain why walls were important for a city.
Explain the significance of the city of Jerusalem.
Perform research on the topography of Jerusalem's walls.
Summarize the story of Naomi's return to Bethlehem.
Explain what a 'Kinsman Redeemer' is.
Explain the levirate marriage custom.
Defend the inclusion of Gentiles in the plan of salvation.
Summarize the story of the fiery furnace.
Explain the dream of the statue made of metals.
Explain the genre of Apocalyptic literature.
Defend the supernatural prediction of future empires.
Produce a study on living faithfully in exile (Babylon).
Summarize the vision of the Dry Bones coming to life.
Explain that God's glory left the temple because of sin.
Categorize Ezekiel as a prophet during the Exile.
Explain the individual responsibility for sin in Ezekiel 18.
Defend the regenerative work of the Spirit (Ezekiel 36).
Summarize Isaiah's call (Here am I, send me).
Explain Isaiah 53 (The Suffering Servant).
Categorize Isaiah as the most quoted prophet in the NT.
Explain the historical context of the Assyrian invasion.
Defend the unity of the book.
Summarize Jeremiah's difficult job (no one listened).
Explain the New Covenant (law written on hearts).
Explain the historical context of the fall of Jerusalem.
Defend the justice of God's judgment on Judah.
Produce a study on the false prophets of Jeremiah's day.
Summarize Amos' warnings to the rich people.
Explain 'Let justice roll down like waters'.
Explain the 'Famine of the Word'.
Defend the importance of righteousness in society.
Produce an essay on the danger of religious hypocrisy.
Summarize Habakkuk's questions (Why do bad people win?).
Explain God's answer (He is using the Babylonians).
Explain the woe oracles against the Chaldeans.
Defend the sovereignty of God in using wicked nations.
Produce a reflection on finding joy in God alone.
Summarize the message: 'Consider your ways'.
Explain why the people stopped building (discouragement).
Explain the 'shaking of the heavens and earth'.
Defend the importance of the visible church/temple.
Produce an essay on overcoming spiritual apathy.
Summarize Hosea's marriage as a picture of God and Israel.
Explain what unfaithfulness means.
Explain the historical context of the Northern Kingdom.
Defend the relentless love of God ('Hesed').
Summarize the plague of locusts.
Explain the promise of the Holy Spirit.
Explain the call to national repentance.
Defend the necessity of repentance for restoration.
Summarize the story of Jonah's running and preaching.
Explain why Jonah was angry (he hated the Assyrians).
Explain the satire and irony in the book.
Defend the historicity of the book against 'parable' views.
Summarize the disputes between God and the people.
Explain the prophecy of the messenger (John the Baptist).
Explain the problem of divorce and intermarriage in Malachi.
Defend the immutability of God ('I the Lord do not change').
Summarize Micah 6:8 (Act justly, love mercy, walk humbly).
Explain the prophecy about Jesus' birth.
Explain the imagery of casting sins into the sea.
Defend the consistency of justice and mercy in God's character.
Produce a reflection on 'Who is a God like you?'
Summarize the judgment on Nineveh.
Explain that Nineveh went back to being bad after Jonah.
Explain why God's patience eventually ends.
Defend the justice of God in history.
Summarize the conflict between Jacob (Israel) and Esau (Edom).
Explain that pride brings people down.
Explain the lex talionis ('As you have done, it shall be done to you').
Defend God's justice in judging nations.
Summarize the prophecy of the King on a donkey (Palm Sunday).
Explain the vision of the lampstand and olive trees.
Explain the concept of the 'Branch'.
Defend the unity of the book (chapters 1-8 and 9-14).
Summarize the warning of judgment on the whole earth.
Explain the 'remnant' (the people who stay faithful).
Explain the image of God as a singing warrior.
Defend the necessity of judgment for true restoration.
Summarize the 'Shema' (Hear, O Israel...).
Explain that Deuteronomy means 'Second Law'.
Explain the significance of Moses' death on Mt. Nebo.
Defend the unity of the Law.
Produce an essay on how Deuteronomy serves as the theological center of the OT.
Summarize the ten plagues and the Passover.
Explain the meaning of 'Exodus' (road out/departure).
Explain the purpose of the Tabernacle dwelling.
Defend the historicity of the event against minimalist claims.
Produce an essay on Exodus as the paradigm for salvation in the Bible.
Summarize the lives of the four Patriarchs (Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, Joseph).
Explain the two main sections: Primeval History (1-11) and Patriarchal History (12-50).
Perform research on the cultural background of patriarchal customs.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Summarize how the Law shows us our sin.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Explain how the sacrifices show us God's grace.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Explain how grace is present even in the Old Testament.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Defend the continuity of salvation by grace through faith in both Testaments.
Summarize the five main offerings (Burnt, Grain, Peace, Sin, Guilt).
Explain what 'Holy' means (set apart/perfect).
Categorize the feasts of Israel found in Leviticus 23.
Explain the role of the Scapegoat.
Defend the necessity of blood sacrifice.
Summarize the search for meaning in pleasure, work, and wisdom.
Explain the phrase 'Meaningless' or 'Vanity'.
Explain the difference between fleeting joy and eternal purpose.
Defend the book's presence in the canon as essential realism.
Summarize the test of Job (losing family and health).
Explain that bad things happen even to good people.
Explain the limit of Satan's power.
Defend the sovereignty of God in suffering.
Explain the difference between knowledge and wisdom.
Explain the warning against the 'Strange Woman' (Folly).
Defend the practical value of Proverbs for modern ethics.
Summarize the different types of Psalms (Praise, Thanksgiving, Lament).
Explain how to use Psalms for prayer.
Explain the use of Selah and other musical terms.
Defend the use of Psalms in corporate worship.
Produce a study on the Kingship of Yahweh in the Psalms.
Summarize it as a poem about a bride and groom.
Explain that marriage is between a man and a woman.
Explain the 'shulammite' woman.
Defend the holiness of physical intimacy within marriage.
Compare the spies in Joshua 2 with the spies in Numbers 13.
Compare the faith of Joshua and Caleb with the fear of the others.
Apply the story of the Bronze Serpent.
Analyze the layout of the camp with the Tabernacle in the center.
Interpret the story of Balaam and his donkey.
Connect the grumbling of Israel to the spiritual danger of discontent.
Compare how Chronicles leaves out David's bad sin (Bathsheba).
Apply the prayer of Jabez or Jehoshaphat.
Analyze why Chronicles was written (for the returning exiles).
Interpret the focus on the Southern Kingdom (Judah) over the North.
Connect the genealogy to the identity of the post-exilic community.
Compare the Northern Kingdom (Israel) and Southern Kingdom (Judah).
Analyze the ministry of Elijah and Elisha (miracles and confrontation).
Interpret the fall of Samaria (722 BC) and Jerusalem (586 BC).
Connect the reforms of Josiah to the Book of the Law.
Compare Saul's disobedience with David's repentance.
Apply the lesson of friendship between David and Jonathan.
Analyze the Davidic Covenant in 2 Samuel 7.
Interpret the fall of the Ark of the Covenant.
Connect David's sin with Bathsheba to the turmoil in his family.
Compare the pride of Haman with the honor of Mordecai.
Apply the phrase 'For such a time as this'.
Analyze the fact that God's name is not mentioned in the book.
Interpret the feast of Purim.
Connect the story to the providence of God.
Compare the first return (Zerubbabel) and second return (Ezra).
Apply Ezra's example of studying and doing God's law.
Analyze the spiritual condition of the returnees.
Interpret the problem of intermarriage in Ezra.
Connect the rebuilding of the altar to true worship.
Apply the verse 'Be strong and courageous'.
Analyze the three military campaigns (Central, Southern, Northern).
Interpret the sun standing still (Joshua 10).
Connect the land allotment to the tribal promises.
Compare the strength of Samson with his weakness for sin.
Analyze the refrain 'In those days there was no king in Israel'.
Interpret the tragic vow of Jephthah.
Connect the moral decline to the religious compromise.
Compare Nehemiah (governor) with Ezra (priest).
Apply Nehemiah's leadership skills.
Analyze the social justice issues Nehemiah addressed (usury).
Interpret the opposition of Sanballat and Tobiah.
Connect the reading of the Law to the renewal of the covenant.
Compare the choice of Orpah (left) and Ruth (stayed).
Apply the loyalty of Ruth to our friendships.
Analyze the literary structure of the book.
Interpret the significance of a Moabite in the line of Christ.
Connect the timeline of Ruth to the period of the Judges.
Compare the pride of Nebuchadnezzar with the humility of Daniel.
Apply the courage to stand up for God.
Analyze the sovereignty of God over nations.
Interpret the vision of the four beasts.
Connect the 'Son of Man' to Jesus.
Compare the heart of stone with the heart of flesh.
Analyze the symbolism of the watchman.
Interpret the vision of the New Temple.
Connect the phrase 'Then they will know that I am the Lord'.
Compare the judgment on idols with the comfort for Israel.
Analyze the two main sections: Judgment (1-39) and Comfort (40-66).
Interpret the Messianic prophecies.
Connect the holiness of God to the need for cleansing.
Compare a true prophet with false prophets who said 'peace'.
Apply the lesson that obeying God is hard but right.
Analyze the acted parables (linen belt, potter's house).
Interpret the Temple Sermon (trusting rituals vs. obeying God).
Connect Jeremiah's suffering to the suffering of Jesus.
Compare religious singing with real obedience.
Apply the lesson of caring for the needy.
Analyze the judgment on the nations in chapters 1-2.
Interpret the vision of the plumb line.
Connect social justice to true worship.
Compare complaining with trusting.
Apply the choice to rejoice in God no matter what (Habakkuk 3).
Analyze the dialogue between the prophet and God.
Interpret 'The just shall live by his faith'.
Connect Habakkuk to the coming Babylonian invasion.
Compare the small new temple with the glorious old one.
Apply the lesson of putting God's work first.
Analyze the connection between spiritual obedience and physical blessing.
Interpret the prophecy that the glory of the latter house will be greater.
Connect Haggai to Zerubbabel and Joshua the Priest.
Compare idolatry to cheating on a spouse.
Apply the call to return to the Lord.
Analyze the metaphor of spiritual adultery.
Interpret the names of Hosea's children (Not my people).
Connect Hosea's redemption of Gomer to Christ redeeming the church.
Compare a natural disaster with God's judgment.
Apply the call to rend hearts, not garments.
Analyze the concept of the 'Day of the Lord'.
Interpret the prophecy of the Spirit quoted in Acts 2.
Connect the locust plague to future judgment.
Compare God's mercy with Jonah's anger.
Apply the lesson that God cares for our enemies.
Analyze Jonah's prayer from the fish.
Interpret the sign of Jonah mentioned by Jesus.
Connect the book to Israel's failure to be a light to the nations.
Compare true worship with bored worship.
Apply the teaching on tithes and offerings.
Analyze the question-and-answer style of the book.
Interpret 'I have loved Jacob but hated Esau'.
Connect the 'Sun of Righteousness' to Jesus.
Compare false rulers with the Good Shepherd.
Apply the call to walk humbly with God.
Analyze the lawsuit motif in the book.
Interpret the prophecy of the mountain of the Lord.
Compare God as a stronghold with God as a flood.
Apply the truth that God judges evil.
Analyze the poetic description of the siege of Nineveh.
Interpret the character of God in Nahum 1.
Connect the fall of Nineveh to historical records.
Compare Edom's rocky fortress with God's power.
Apply the warning against pride.
Analyze the historical background of Edom.
Interpret 'The day of the Lord is near for all nations'.
Connect the judgment of Edom to the protection of Zion.
Compare the bad shepherds with the Good Shepherd.
Apply the promise of God's Spirit helping us.
Analyze the eight night visions.
Interpret the prophecy of the 30 pieces of silver.
Connect Zechariah to the rebuilding of the Temple.
Compare the bad day for enemies with the glad day for God's people.
Apply the verse 'He will quiet you with His love'.
Analyze the de-creation language in Zephaniah 1.
Interpret the call to seek righteousness and humility.
Connect Zephaniah to the reign of Josiah.
Compare the blessings for obeying and the curses for disobeying.
Apply the command to teach God's word to children.
Analyze the structure of the book as a Suzerain-Vassal treaty.
Interpret the requirement for the future King.
Connect Deuteronomy to Jesus' temptation (He quoted it 3 times).
Compare the slavery in Egypt to freedom in the wilderness.
Apply the lesson that God rescues His people.
Analyze the structure: Deliverance (1-18), Covenant (19-24), Tabernacle (25-40).
Interpret the significance of the Divine Name (Yahweh/I AM).
Connect the Passover Lamb to Christ.
Compare the creation account with the fall of man.
Analyze the structure of the 'Toledot' (generations) throughout the book.
Interpret the significance of the Abrahamic Covenant for world history.
Connect the 'seed of the woman' promise to the rest of the book.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Compare trying to be good with trusting in God.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Apply the idea that the Law is a guide for how to live, not how to be saved.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Analyze the Three Uses of the Law (Mirror, Restraint, Guide).

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Interpret Paul's statement that the Law is a 'tutor' to lead us to Christ.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Connect the failure of Israel to keep the Law with the need for a New Covenant.
Compare clean and unclean animals.
Analyze the Day of Atonement ceremony (Leviticus 16).
Interpret the call to 'Be holy, for I am holy.'
Connect the dietary laws to the idea of separation from the nations.
Compare life 'under the sun' with life with God.
Apply the conclusion: Fear God and keep His commandments.
Analyze the reality of death and injustice in the book.
Interpret the call to remember the Creator in youth.
Connect Ecclesiastes to the dissatisfaction of materialism.
Compare Job's patience with his friends' bad advice.
Apply the truth that we should trust God even when we don't understand.
Analyze the dialogue between Job and his three friends.
Interpret God's answer from the whirlwind.
Connect the book to the problem of evil (Theodicy).
Compare the sluggard (lazy person) with the ant.
Apply proverbs about words and anger to daily life.
Analyze the structure: Father's instruction vs. Woman Wisdom.
Interpret the nature of a proverb (general truth, not absolute promise).
Connect wisdom to the order of creation.
Compare Psalm 1 (The Righteous) and Psalm 2 (The Messiah).
Apply a Psalm to your own feelings.
Analyze the structure of Hebrew poetry (Parallelism).
Interpret the Messianic Psalms (e.g., 22, 110).
Connect the five books of Psalms to the Torah.
Compare the love in the book to God's love for the church.
Apply the idea of loyalty in relationships.
Analyze the poetic language of love and devotion.
Interpret the book as a celebration of marital intimacy.
Connect the marriage covenant to the biblical view of sexuality.
Explain the theology of Election in the choice of Jacob over Esau.
Evaluate the character flaws of Moses that kept him from the Promised Land.
Evaluate the theological purpose of idealizing David and Solomon.
Evaluate the role of the prophet vis--vis the king.
Evaluate the character of Absalom and his rebellion.
Evaluate the moral complexity of Esther's marriage to a pagan king.
Evaluate the exclusivity of the post-exilic community.
Evaluate the archaeological record of the destruction of Hazor.
Evaluate the disturbing ending of the book (civil war).
Evaluate the effectiveness of the reforms (did they last?).
Evaluate the role of providence in the book (God is never named as acting directly).
Evaluate the dating of Daniel (6th century vs. Maccabean).
Evaluate the apocalyptic imagery in the book.
Evaluate the critical theory of Deutero-Isaiah.
Evaluate the promise of the New Covenant in Jeremiah 31.
Evaluate the economic prosperity vs. moral decay of Israel.
Evaluate Paul's use of Habakkuk 2:4 in Romans and Galatians.
Evaluate the messianic significance of the signet ring.
Evaluate the shock value of the prophetic sign act.
Evaluate the use of Joel in Peter's Pentecost sermon.
Evaluate the ending of the book (the unanswered question).
Evaluate the prophecy of Elijah and its fulfillment in John the Baptist.
Evaluate the Messianic Shepherd-King prophecy.
Evaluate the moral necessity of divine wrath against cruelty.
Evaluate the sin of gloating over another's misfortune.
Evaluate the apocalyptic imagery and its relation to Revelation.
Evaluate the syncretism (mixing religions) condemned in the book.
Evaluate the 'Deuteronomic History' hypothesis.
Evaluate the date of the Exodus (Early vs. Late date).
Evaluate the literary framework view of Genesis 1 versus literal creationism.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Evaluate the error of legalism vs. antinomianism.
Evaluate the relevance of the Holiness Code for New Testament believers.
Evaluate the authorship debate (Solomon vs. later sage).
Evaluate the role of Elihu.
Evaluate the personification of Wisdom in chapter 8.
Evaluate the imprecatory Psalms (prayers for judgment).
Evaluate the biblical view of sexuality vs. cultural views.
Construct a timeline of the wilderness wanderings.
Synthesize the typology of the wilderness as the Christian life.
Construct a comparison of Kings (prophetic history) vs. Chronicles (priestly history).
Synthesize the hope for the Son of David found in Chronicles.
Construct a synchronized timeline of the divided monarchy.
Construct a contrast between theocratic rule and monarchical rule.
Synthesize the messianic themes in the Song of Hannah and David's Last Words.
Construct an argument for the book's canonicity.
Construct a timeline of the Persian kings in Ezra.
Synthesize the relationship between Ezra and Nehemiah.
Construct a defense of the morality of the Canaanite conquest.
Synthesize the theme of 'Rest' in Joshua and the NT.
Construct a chart of the Judges and their geographical areas.
Construct a profile of biblical leadership based on Nehemiah.
Synthesize the theme of prayer and action in the book.
Construct a character study of Boaz as a type of Christ.
Synthesize the book as a bridge between Judges and the Monarchy.
Construct a timeline of the 'Seventy Weeks' prophecy.
Construct a diagram of the departure and return of God's glory.
Synthesize Ezekiel's temple vision with Revelation.
Synthesize the vision of the New Heavens and New Earth.
Construct a profile of Jeremiah's inner life and complaints.
Construct a theological response to the problem of evil based on Habakkuk.
Construct a timeline of the post-exilic period (Ezra/Haggai).
Synthesize Hosea's message with the New Testament bride imagery.
Construct a timeline of the fulfillment of Joel 2.
Synthesize the theme of judgment and blessing.
Construct a profile of the Assyrian cruelty to understand Jonah's reluctance.
Synthesize the missionary heart of God in the OT.
Construct a profile of the spiritual lethargy of the post-exilic community.
Synthesize the end of the OT and the 400 years of silence.
Connect Micah's message to his contemporary, Isaiah.
Construct a comparison of Jonah (mercy) and Nahum (judgment).
Synthesize the comfort Nahum brings to God's oppressed people.
Construct a history of the Edomite/Israelite conflict.
Synthesize the theme of the Kingdom belonging to the Lord.
Construct a list of Messianic prophecies in Zechariah.
Synthesize the theme of the piercing of the Messiah.
Construct a study on the 'Day of the Lord' theme.
Synthesize the joy of restoration in Zephaniah 3.
Construct a map of the possible routes of the Exodus.
Construct a defense of Mosaic authorship against the Documentary Hypothesis.
Synthesize the theme of God's sovereignty in the Joseph narrative.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Synthesize the Torah as a witness to Christ.
Synthesize the book of Leviticus with the book of Hebrews.
Construct a philosophical apologetic using Ecclesiastes.
Construct a summary of the retribution principle and how Job refutes it.
Synthesize Job as a type of the righteous sufferer (Christ).
Construct a topical study of Proverbs (money, speech, friendship).
Synthesize the 'Proverbs 31 Woman' as an ideal of wisdom.
Construct a comparison of literal vs. allegorical interpretations.
Synthesize the Song with the 'Bride of Christ' imagery in the NT.
Construct a theology of the 'Holy One of Israel'.
Construct a theology of social justice based on Amos.
Construct a theology of God's emotional engagement (jealousy/love).
Construct a theology of what God requires of man.
Construct a theology of the 'heart' in Deuteronomy.
Construct a theology of substitutionary atonement based on Leviticus.
Construct a theology of the emotions based on the Psalms.

objectives.sub_topic_name: Law and Gospel in the Pentateuch
objectives.objective_text: Construct a clear distinction between Law and Gospel hermeneutics.
